definition[0]: to buy something in large quantities
example[0]: Companies are buying in supplies of paper, in case the price goes up.
definition[1]: if an organization buys in parts or services, it gets them from another company, rather than produce them itself
example[1]: Under the new system, schools have to buy in the services of advisers and librarians.
definition[2]: when a company buys its own shares from existing shareholders
example[2]: A buy-in has the advantage of removing small shareholders and frees the parent company to run the unit.
